newsitem.title: FRANCE: French planes stay south of 30th parallel in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: French planes stay south of 30th parallel in Iraq.

text.p: France denied on Wednesday a U.S. Defence Department statement that its combat aircraft had joined U.S. and British planes in patrolling an extended no-fly zone over Iraq up to the 33rd parallel.
After some confusion over whether the French planes flew at all on Wednesday and where, the foreign ministry said they stayed south of the 30th parallel.
"The French planes took part on September 4 to usual missions of defence of Saudi airspace south of the 30th parallel," ministry spokesman Yves Doutriaux said.
The 30th parallel embraces Kuwait and a narrow slice of Iraqi territory south of Basrah.
Government officials had said earlier that no French planes had taken off for several days.

They then said the planes took part in patrols of a no-fly exclusion zone over southern Iraq on Wednesday but stayed south of the 32nd parallel -- without going beyond the original no-fly zone set in the wake of the 1991 Gulf War.
Foreign Minister Herve de Charette, speaking at a news conference with visiting Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa, had refused to confirm or deny the U.S. Defence Department report.
Deflecting direct questions, he said repeatedly: "France is examining the consequences of the decision taken by the United Nations to change the limits of the southern (exclusion) zone."
France withheld support from President Bill Clinton's cruise missile raids on Iraq to punish President Saddam Hussein for sending troops into Kurdish areas of northern Iraq.

It also indicated it had not agreed in advance to Clinton's extension of the no-fly zone which the three Western powers have policed since a U.S.-led coalition drove Iraqi invasion forces out of Kuwait in 1991.
